pull.title: tests: Dry run bench_bitcoin as part "make check" to allow for quick identification of assertion/sanitizer failures in benchmarking code
pull.body:
Dry run `bench_bitcoin` (`-evals=1 -scaling=0`: <1 second running time) as part `make check` to allow for quick identification of assertion/sanitizer failures or crashes in benchmarking code.

This is already tested in Travis but it is nice to have it locally too. The cost is near zero.

rename.from: tests: Dry run bench_bitcoin (-evals=1 -scaling=0: <1 second running time) as part "make check" to allow for quick identification of assertion/sanitizer failures in benchmarking code
rename.to: tests: Dry run bench_bitcoin as part "make check" to allow for quick identification of assertion/sanitizer failures in benchmarking code

events.body:
in this case you'll probably want to remove the RUN_BENCH logic from travis as it does pretty much the same (introduced in #13811)
ping @MarcoFalke
@laanwj Yes, that is my plan if @MarcoFalke is OK with it :-)
I don't see any downside to doing this. So Concept ACK, but I can't review build system changes.

issue.title: tests: Run functional test on Windows and enable it on Appveyor
issue.body:
This PR do the following things:
- Make functional tests compatible with Windows
- Print color output in functional tests for Windows 10
- Run util and functional tests on appveyor
- Do not run symlink tests on Windows

Note:
- The wallet_multiwallet.py fail is unrelated to the test framework, it's a bug related to c++ code or maybe dependencies. `bitcoind` would exit with 0xC0000005(Access violation) during shutdown occasionally. Disable this for now.
- Not using `--failfast` because this is still in experimental. We should track if there is any other error.
- Disable ZMQ tests because the python zmq library could cause access violation sometimes.
- Disable `feature_notifications` because Bitcoin Core handles the command in different thread, whicha can cause a race condition.

events.message: tests: Dry run bench_bitcoin (-evals=1 -scaling=0: <1 second running time) as part "make check" to allow for quick identification of assertion/sanitizer failures in benchmarking code

issue.title: wallet: Remove unused local variable old_label
issue.body:
Remove unused local variable `old_label`.

Last use was removed in #13825.

issue.title: build: Run functional tests and benchmarks under the undefined behaviour sanitizer (UBSan)
issue.body:
Run functional tests and benchmarks under the undefined behaviour sanitizer (UBSan).

This will make Travis automatically detect issues such as:
* #14242: Avoid triggering undefined behaviour (`std::memset(nullptr, 0, 0)`) if an invalid string is passed to `DecodeSecret(...)`
* #14239: Avoid dividing by zero (undefined behaviour) in `EstimateMedianVal` (policy)/`ConnectTip` (validation)/`CreateTransaction` (wallet)
* #13546: wallet: Avoid potential use of uninitialized value `bnb_used` in `CWallet::CreateTransaction(...)`

Addresses issue #14059.

events.body:

### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* [#14252](https://drahtbot.github.io/bitcoin_core_issue_redirect/r/14252.html) (build: Run functional tests and benchmarks under the undefined behaviour sanitizer (UBSan) by practicalswift)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.
Concept ACK dfef0df8406528915aaa718e761ce9eaab14ee37, can't review the build system changes, though.

Tested by merging dfef0df and then applying the changes from #14011 (so that make check actually runs on macOS).

Got the bench output:
```
OK
Running bench/bench_bitcoin -evals=1 -scaling=0...
bench/bench_bitcoin -evals=1 -scaling=0 > /dev/null
.....
```

Added an `assert(0)` to `AssembleBlock` to check that a failure is caught.
```
OK
Running bench/bench_bitcoin -evals=1 -scaling=0...
bench/bench_bitcoin -evals=1 -scaling=0 > /dev/null
Assertion failed: (0), function AssembleBlock, file bench/block_assemble.cpp, line 57.
/bin/sh: line 1: 60728 Abort trap: 6           bench/bench_bitcoin -evals=1 -scaling=0 > /dev/null
make[3]: *** [check-local] Error 134
make[2]: *** [check-am] Error 2
make[1]: *** [check-recursive] Error 1
make: *** [check-recursive] Error 1
```

Probably worth getting @theuni to glance over the test.include changes pre-merge.

issue.title: Fix bench_bitcoin on auxpow branch
issue.body:
Since https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14092, upstream Bitcoin runs `bench_bitcoin` as part of `make check`.  `bench_bitcoin` has long been broken with `auxpow` and Namecoin itself, but until that change it didn't matter too much.  With that change, I had to disable `bench_bitcoin` by just returning early.

We should look into why it fails on the `auxpow` branch and properly fixing this.

labels.name: auxpow
labels.description: Auxilliary Proof of Work (not Namecoin per se)

issue.title: bench is broken
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
The benchmark aborts during run in both debug- and non-debug builds.

```
20:02:09 julian@pithos.local:~/Github/dtr-org/unit-e (0)
$ src/bench/bench_unite
# Benchmark, evals, iterations, total, min, max, median
Base58CheckEncode, 5, 320000, 5.7853, 3.56112e-06, 3.66382e-06, 3.61205e-06
Base58Decode, 5, 800000, 3.81941, 9.31963e-07, 9.98394e-07, 9.39375e-07
Base58Encode, 5, 470000, 5.61155, 2.3527e-06, 2.4373e-06, 2.3656e-06
BenchLockedPool, 5, 530, 4.53961, 0.00166907, 0.00176909, 0.00171432
CCheckQueueSpeedPrevectorJob, 5, 1400, 11.4961, 0.00162273, 0.0016537, 0.00164538
CCoinsCaching, 5, 170000, 6.61286, 7.65729e-06, 7.85283e-06, 7.81281e-06
CoinSelection, 5, 650, 5.76141, 0.00173051, 0.00180892, 0.00178562
Assertion failed: (stream.Rewind(sizeof(block_bench::block413567))), function DeserializeAndCheckBlockTest, file bench/checkblock.cpp, line 48.
Abort trap: 6
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run `src/bench/bench_unite`
2. Wait
3. See it fail

**Expected behavior**
Should exit with zero exit code and present all the benchmarks.

**Environment**
master, macOS and linux: 18631505730e02c0104996938b8375f63065470f

comments.body: Does scaling=0 actually run everything at least once? If not, just set to a small value larger than zero.
